esmModelGrid.description:
The grid utilised by the HadGEM1 atmosphere model is based upon a combination of an Arakawa C-grid for horizontal coordinates and a 38-level Charnley-Phillips grid for vertical coordinates. Together they define a set of staggered grid locations (nodes) in the horizontal and vertical planes. Grid positions are defined by spherical polar coordinates; that is, (lon,lat,r) where r represents a hybrid parameterised, terrain-following vertical coordinate. Within this framework the grid positions of the four primary model variables, P, u, v, w, are referenced as follows:
P = (i-0.5, j-0.5, k-0.5) u = (i, j-0.5, k-0.5) v = (i-0.5, j, k-0.5) w = (i-0.5, j-0.5, k)
where i, j and k represent whole-integral planes in model space, and i-0.5, j-0.5 and k-0.5 represent half-integral planes. Index coordinates (i,j,k) correspond to physical coordinates (lon,lat,r). The UM N96 grid is based upon a spherical Earth with radius 6371229 m.
Some salient facts concerning use of the UM N96 grid: - Array indexing in the latitude direction starts at the south pole. - For an unrotated grid mesh, longitude(i=0.5) == Greenwich meridian. - In the UM, the north and south poles coincide with the bounding half-integer j planes, i.e. j = 0.5 and j = M-0.5. - P-points and u-points exist at the poles, but not v-points. - At the poles all values of P are set equal. Likewise for scalar variables rho, theta, m, w. - The vertical levels are terrain-following for levels up to k = 29.

gridTile.description: The P-grid defines the locations of the scalar (P) variables computed by the model. P locations lie at the centre of the 'grid molecule' used to represent the relative positions of the P, u, v, and w variables.
